properties.Disposal area: probably a temporarily abandoned zone, no remains of habitation
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: slightly trapezoidal shape, constituted by walls in rectangular bricks (25/30 x 12/16 x 6/8 cm), long sides preserved 2 courses, while at the head 5 bricks placed slightly corbelled could have belonged to a cover; near the skeleton traces of white seem to be the remains of a mat that enveloped the body
properties.Alignment (orientation): E-W (head E), face directed to N
properties.Body position: on back, legs extended, arms folded on the chest, hands in front of face
properties.Vessels (pottery): behind head, half recessed in wall: 1 conical goblet in fine ceramic (fig. 167.1), 1 small carinated jar in very fine "eggshell"-like ware with painted decoration (fig. 167.2)
properties.Tools: behind head, half recessed in wall: 1 silex knife
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: around body: several oval pebbles
properties.Other excavator notes: part of the sides of the basin had disappeared, having been cut by a "child" burial of the Islamic period (t. 546)

properties.Disposal area: probably a temporarily abandoned zone, no remains of habitation
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: walls positioned ca. 20 cm inside the pit cut for the burial; made of bricks placed vertically (27 x 12 x 7 cm)
properties.Body position: on back, flexed, arms folded, hands at head height
properties.Vessels (pottery): placed between brick wall and wall of pit: hemispherical bowl in shiny black ceramic (fig. 277.1), painted carinated fine paste bowl (fig. 277.2), cylindrical bowl (fig. 288.1)
properties.Other excavator notes: body appears to have been enveloped in a mat
properties.Data collator notes: contained Susa I vessel

properties.Disposal area: probably a temporarily abandoned zone, no remains of habitation
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: only one of the walls preserved
properties.Vessels (pottery): conical goblet in common ware (fig. 175.1) and small painted jar (fig. 175.2)
properties.Other excavator notes: very disturbed by burials of the Islamic period and by proximity to the surface; only a wall, femur, tibia, and two vessels found

properties.Disposal area: probably a temporarily abandoned zone, no remains of habitation
properties.Alignment (orientation): seems to be NE-SW, face directed to N
properties.Body position: one "limb" folded, hands toward the face
properties.Other excavator notes: cut by sondage II of R. de Mequenem; only part of the skeleton remains (the skull, one limb); all around the skeleton in the fill of the pit were fragments of mat

properties.Disposal area: probably a temporarily abandoned zone, no remains of habitation
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: a pit against the wall of which rested walls of brick (40 x 22 x 10 cm); 11 bricks rested diagonally, transversally (crosswise) to the axis of the burial, as a cover
properties.Other excavator notes: burial cut through a wall of level 16, was in turn cut at the west extremity by a wall of level 12 (i.e. probably pre-Susa I; indicating this burial type goes back further); the bricks of the cover and the skull had disappeared, as well as the funerary vessels that must have been situated in this part; only 6 vertebrae, 2 ulnae, and a fragment of radius were found

properties.Disposal area: probably a temporarily abandoned zone, no remains of habitation
properties.Other excavator notes: only some bones found (scapula, vertebrae)

properties.Disposal area: probably a temporarily abandoned zone, no remains of habitation

properties.Alignment (orientation): N-S (head N), face directed to W
properties.Body position: on back, head turned on right side
properties.Other excavator notes: "child" skeleton; no grave goods

properties.Disposal area: immediately below a protoliterate floor
properties.Other excavator notes: very decayed burial; no grave goods; "Protoliterate" date

properties.Disposal area: just below modern surface

properties.Other excavator notes: Sukkalmah sherds in fill; no grave goods

properties.Alignment (orientation): slight SE-NW, face directed to S
properties.Other excavator notes: partly destroyed skeleton

ashy debris around burial
ashy debris around burial; "Protoliterate" date

properties.date: Pre-Susa I (Late Middle Susiana, ca. 5000-4800 BCE)
properties.Alignment (orientation): SW-NE (head SW), face directed to NW
properties.Vessels (pottery): at head: late Middle Susiana bowl (pl. 164:H)
properties.Other excavator notes: partly destroyed skeleton, 1.74 m long

properties.Disposal area: near a Protoliterate catch basin
properties.Other excavator notes: scattered human bones near the cup suggest this was a burial
burial either inside or accompanied by a vessel

properties.Disposal area: in a room of a monumental building complex of Protoliterate era
properties.Other excavator notes: Protoliterate, or could have been cut into the building during a later period; lower jaw and lower legs missing; no grave goods

properties.Disposal area: late Susiana architecture
properties.Alignment (orientation): E-W (head E), face directed to E
properties.Body position: on back, legs extended (roughly drawn in fig. 7)
properties.Other excavator notes: architecture is late Susiana 2 (ca. 4400-4200 BCE), but vessel is Sukkalmah

properties.Disposal area: late Susiana 2-dated building - next to southern wall of a long room with mud-plastered walls (N10:1010)
properties.Other excavator notes: possible burial with a few badly preserved bones

properties.Disposal area: tomb building (parallel to the "mass burial chamber", id HaT2)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: rectangular (l. 12.90 m, w. 5.80 m) baked brick tomb, arched vaulted roof (h. 1.40-3.37 m); gypsum mortar between the bricks; burial chamber (10 x 3.25 x 7.75 m) contains a baked brick burial platform (8.10 x 2.90 x 0.40 m) that covers most of the floor, leaving a narrow passage on the eastern wall and an open floor area at the southern end; platform divided into 3 sections by 2 inner partitions and bordered by a low wall (h. 15 cm) with drainage holes (w. 10 cm); a coat of gypsum covered all surfaces of the tomb and burial platform; an entrance at the southern wall connects to Hall no.1
properties.Alignment (orientation): 7 individuals on north side of platform: W-E (head W), face directed to S
properties.Body position: 7 individuals on north side of platform: set down on right side with heads next to west wall, legs flexed and feet toward east wall
properties.Vessels (pottery): southern section of platform: elongated pottery vessel
properties.Other excavator notes: 7 individuals set down parallel to one another on northern section of the platform, at least 2 individuals in the southern section, 12 more carelessly dumped inside the southern entrance; remains of red ochre on the platform and on the skeletons, indicating that after a ritual washing the bodies were covered by a rather thick layer of this pigment; two sun-dried brick walls separate this tomb and the "mass burial tomb" (id HaT2)

properties.Disposal area: tomb building (northwest corner, parallel to so-called tomb of Tepti-Ahar, id HaT1)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: baked brick tomb (l. 5.20 m, w. 2.65 m, inner room l. 4.80, w. 1.85 m), originally an arched vaulted roof (only preserved to h. 0.30 m), less carefully constructed than the "Tepti Ahar" tomb; no constructed entrance, the southern end connecting to Hall no. 2 blocked only by roughly placed baked bricks
properties.Body position: 14 individuals (side by side): legs extended, the in situ photograph suggests arms at various degrees of flexion at elbow
properties.Vessels (pottery): 1 small conical pottery bowl with a circular flat base
properties.Other excavator notes: 14 individuals placed side by side widthways in the tomb, the first 4 near the entrance (south side) seem to have a particular relation to each other, 9 more individuals dumped over the lower limbs of the first 14; the vaulted roof seems to have been destroyed by the levelling activities of the sugar cane plantation; two sun-dried brick walls separate this tomb and the "tomb of Tepti Ahar" (id HaT1)

properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: large vessels, in some instances surrounded by a sundried brick wall
properties.Other excavator notes: vessels apparently only large enough to be used for very young "children", and only one per vessel
properties.Data collator notes: ids Hat4-5 belong to this group

properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: in situ photograph shows a side-set broken vessel with a shoulder moulding and possibly ridges below the mouth; its complete form is not visible, but it is possibly similar to a vessel from the early second millennium BCE Building Level I at Haft Tepe (Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2016, fig. 7, H.T. 12-436-17)
properties.Data collator notes: belongs to group id Hat3-G; photograph shows burial in situ beside another vessel burial id Hat5 set on its side and probably dating to the early Sukkalmah period, but this one appears to be cut into the wall surrounding the latter and is therefore probably slightly later; placement of the vessel on its side is seen also in several contemporary vessel burials at Susa (Gasche 2000)

properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: in situ photograph shows a side-placed vessel with a small foot, shoulder moulding, and incised lines under the lip [cf. vessel with similar shape, moulding and incised lines in Gasche 1973, group 36c, pl. 47.3, Ville Royale B V burial t.164]; vessel surrounded by a sun dried brick wall
properties.Data collator notes: belongs to group id Hat3-G; date proposed based on burial vessel comparanda from Ville Royale B V at Susa (t.164, not included in this id, but similarly placed on its side as were several other contemporary vessel burials from Susa in Gasche 2000), and the closest form published from Haft Tepe is from the early second millennium Building Level I documented by Mofidi-Nasrabadi (2016, fig. 7, H.T. 12-436-17); photograph shows this burial in situ beside vessel burial id Hat4, which is probably slightly later as it cuts into the surrounding wall

properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: overturned large vessels ("inverted over the body")
properties.Other excavator notes: one individual per vessel
properties.Data collator notes: one of these photographed in situ is described a "basin", but is in fact likely an overturned coffin (id HaT12)

properties.square_locus: E XVII, F XVIII and G XVIII
properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness)
properties.Body position: set on one side with legs flexed
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: in some burials: "other items"
properties.Data collator notes: ids HaT8-10 belong to this group

properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness)
properties.Body position: on right side, legs tightly flexed (ca. 10°) at both hips and knees, arms appear to be tightly flexed at elbow
properties.Data collator notes: one of id HaT7-G; date suggested based on the presence of two probably early Sukkalmah juvenile vessel burials (ids Hat4-5) in the same square EXVIIl; no grave goods visible in the in situ photograph

properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness)
properties.Body position: difficult to discern in the in situ photograph, legs appear to be flexed
properties.Vessels (pottery): in situ photograph shows 3 goblets set down together [similar profile cups at Susa, cf. Gasche 1973, group 21b, pl. 22.16, Ville Royale A XIII, 3 and 7, Ville Royale A XII, and 2, Ville Royale A XI]
properties.Data collator notes: one of id HaT7-G; date suggested based on terracotta vessel comparisons from Susa Ville Royale A XIII-XI

properties.Disposal area: amongst "Elamite" constructions with sundried mudbrick walls of (0.50-2.0 m thickness); wall visible beside the burial in the in situ photograph
properties.Body position: too difficult to discern in the in situ photograph
properties.Vessels (pottery): in situ photograph shows at least 1 goblet similar to that in id HaT9 with comparanda at Susa [cf. Gasche 1973, group 21b, pl. 22.16, Ville Royale A XIII, 3 and 7, Ville Royale A XII, and 2, Ville Royale A XI], the foot of 1 similar vessel and the narrow neck of a (perfume-)bottle with broad, flat lip and probably globular body
properties.Data collator notes: one of id HaT7-G; the in situ photograph labelled "an Elamite burial" shows what appear to be more than one set of human bones, but the number of skulls is not clear; vessel comparisons suggest a similar in date to id HaT9 (probably early Middle Elamite)

properties.level_stratigraphy: "at the rather considerable depth of nearly 2 m from the surface"
properties.Disposal area: west of tomb building
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: clay coffin, Wicks 2024 type 3; Negahban indicated that the "lid" had collapsed into the coffin; however, the in situ photograph appears to show the coffin in an overturned position, as it is presently displayed in the Haft Tappeh Museum; bitumen coated, traces of thick palm-fiber rope soaked in bitumen between horizontal mouldings, h. 47 cm, l. 155/132 cm (rim/base), w. 59/55 cm (rim/base)
properties.Data source: Negahban 1991: 22, plan 3, pl. 19a-b (in situ photographs); Wicks 2024, HTN1, plans 16-17 (location marked)

properties.trench_location: cut 3, in the middle area of Complex C

properties.Disposal area: dug into a ruined building

properties.Disposal area: structure (house?) close to the administrative building in the city's south: house probably already uninhabited (just after destruction of admin building) when burial placed in room 19, in parallel to the southeast wall (grave cover almost at floor level); room 19 was one of 4 rooms (19-22) on the east side of court 13
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: terracotta coffin (length slightly over 100 cm; see image with scale), head end of body covered by half of a large ceramic vessel; large ceramic fragments lay over the lower half of coffin
properties.Alignment (orientation): SW-NE (head SW), face directed to approximately SSE
properties.Body position: legs flexed, arms flexed [hands in front of face?]
properties.Vessels (pottery): outside coffin at foot end: 1 globular ceramic bottle (HT 10-32-33); inside coffin: at forehead, 1 globular ceramic bottle (HT 10-32-19), at mouth, 1 globular ceramic bottle (HT 10-32-20), behind hip, fragment of 1 small round ceramic bottle (HT 10-32-29), at chest, 1 small painted round ceramic vial (HT 10-32-23)
properties.Vessels (silicious): inside coffin: at chest 1 glazed pyxis (HT 10-32-22)
properties.Vessels (metal): inside coffin: below chin 1 copper/bronze cup (HT 10-32-21)
properties.Jewellery: inside coffin: at shoulder, behind head, and on skull, 3 copper/bronze pins with agate bead (HT 10-32-24,25,30), in front of face and on chest, 2 copper/bronze earrings (HT 10-32-27, 28), necklace of gold and stone beads (HT 10-32-34)
properties.Glyptic: inside coffin: at waist, 1 lapis cylinder seal with gold caps (HT 10-32-26), at neck, 1 stone cylinder seal (HT 10-32 -31), both have almost identical Akkadian inscriptions of a Ginadu, a high official (puhu-teppu) of Inshushinak-shar-ilani, and both show an adoration scene with a seated deity and standing human worshipper (in one case a female)
properties.Other excavator notes: sex of skeleton (H.T. 10-32-32) cannot be determined with certainty based on an examination: certain characteristics show female, but some also male characteristics (pelvis not preserved well enough to study)
properties.Data collator notes: building level date follows Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2016

properties.trench_location: under room 8, "hypogeum palace" in the "royal quarter"
properties.Disposal area: 70 x 56 m unbaked brick tomb building with 5 subfloor tomb chambers
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, l. 12.60 m, w. 3.65 m, h. 3.80 at key, baked bricks of normal 35 x 35 x 10 cm format used throughout (for all 5 tombs in building), vault rests on long walls, from beginning of vault each brick overhangs previous by a few cm, and the bricks gradually tilt following curve of vault until 7 vertically placed bricks form the key (irregular radius of 1.72 m at start and 1.65 m at key certainly intended, as the large diameter and lack of specially moulded bricks necessitated a larger key); entered by 17-step staircase covered by 2 vaults made of half-bricks and whole bricks gradually inclined to arrive at 1 vertically placed brick (key) flanked on each side by 2 bricks wedged at upper ends by fragments of bricks cut into a point, lower vault formed tomb door at foot of staircase, h. 1.90 m at key, w. 1.04 m, resting on 13 courses of bricks, the higher vault, w. 0.95 m, rested on it and on the side walls of the staircase (27 courses), and was surmounted by a 1.65 m wall that faced the staircase; opening at top of staircase l. 2.5 m, w. 2 m, flanked on each side by 3 layers of baked bricks set on long sides in recesses of w. 50 cm and coated with bitumen; joints of chamber and staircase vaults all 1.5 cm composed of 1 layer of bitumen between 2 layers of lime, vaults and walls covered with a 1.5 cm layer of lime coated with plaster; a similar lime-bitumen coating covered the ground under a paving of baked bricks; access to tomb blocked from below with unbaked bricks, 2 layers of baked bricks placed on frame to seal opening, and on recesses rested a slight arch of baked bricks placed on-end and pottery sherds
properties.Other excavator notes: 13th century date; only tomb in building composed of a single room with entrance on narrow end, tomb sealed, but empty and unused; located flush with southeast wall of room 8, and so close to this wall that one must enter its staircase by jumping sideways on the first step; generally, the position of the tombs in relation to the building above suggests that the tombs were built first and after their completion the building was constructed above with errors in the planning
properties.Data source: Ghirshman 1968: 59-62, pl. XXXVIII; plan XI, fig. 24
properties.Data collator notes: for recent discussion of the "hypogeum palace" tomb construction and materials see Niroumand, H., Hosseini, S., Gültekin, A. B., Barceló, J. A., Osmadi, A., and Mahdavi, F. 2020. Structural analysis of earth construction’s vaults: Case of underground tombs of Chogha Zanbil. Revista De La Construcción. Journal of Construction, 19/3, 366–80.

properties.trench_location: under rooms 11 and 17, "hypogeum palace" in the "royal quarter"
properties.Disposal area: 70 x 56 m unbaked brick tomb building with 5 subfloor tomb chambers
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: 2 perpendicularly set vaulted chambers, both with cremated human remains, l. 6.25/6.85 m, h./w. almost 4 m, baked bricks of normal 35 x 35 x 10 cm format used throughout (for all 5 tombs in building), vault rests on long walls, from beginning of vault each brick overhangs previous by a few cm, and bricks gradually tilt following curve of vault until 7 vertically placed bricks form the key (irregular radius of 1.72 m at start and 1.65 m at key certainly intended, as the large diameter and lack of specially moulded bricks necessitated a larger key); 1st chamber entered via an unbaked brick arched door (h. 2.37 m) against which 18 layers of baked bricks had been raised at the bottom of a staircase of 17 steps (h. 5.45 m), staircase vault made of gradually inclined half-bricks and whole bricks with a key of 1 vertically placed brick flanked on each side by 2 bricks wedged at upper ends by fragments of bricks cut into a point; joints of chamber and staircase vaults all 1.5 cm composed of 1 layer of bitumen between 2 layers of lime, vaults and walls covered with a 1.5 cm layer of lime coated with plaster; opening to staircase framed by two rows of baked bricks laid parallel, 2 recesses ½ a brick wide at top of staircase coated with bitumen, surmounted by 2 beds of baked bricks set one on top of the other to seal opening, entire staircase sealed off with unbaked bricks.
properties.Jewellery: 1st chamber: beads (pls. XL, 3, XC, G.T.Z. 988), fragment of 1 silver torque (?) (G.T.Z. 989), buttons (G.T.Z. 908), necklace remains (G.T.Z. 837); 2nd chamber:  1 copper/bronze ring (G.T.Z. 995), stone and frit beads (G.T.Z. 993)
properties.Weapons: 1st chamber: 2 stone inlay elements of a sword hilt (pls. XL, 2, XC, G.T.Z. 910), 1 copper/bronze arrowhead (pls. XL, 4, XC, G.T.Z. 838); 2nd chamber: 1 copper/bronze arrow (pls. XL,5, XC, G.T.Z. 996)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: 1st chamber: fragments of bitumen objects (G.T.Z. 907), 1 bitumen button (G.T.Z. 990), 3 inscribed unbaked clay “olives” (pls. XL, 7-9, XC, G.T.Z. 906; G.T.Z. 905, G.T.Z. 992), fragmentary white stone inlays (G.T.Z. 991); 2nd chamber: pieces of cast copper/bronze (pl. XL, 6)
properties.Other excavator notes: 13th century date; a small pile of ashes and half-burnt human bones of 3 individuals in back of first room, a similar pile of 5 individuals at back of second room; sieved remains demonstrated that the dead had been cremated somewhere outside with their grave goods, which were also destroyed by fire, the ashes wrapped in fabric, and deposited in the tomb; evidence of flooding and collapse of the chamber; generally, the position of the tombs in relation to the building above suggests that the tombs were built first and after their completion the building was constructed above with errors in the planning
properties.Data source: Ghirshman 1968: 59, 62-65, pl. XXXIX, XL; plan XI, fig. 25
properties.Data collator notes: for recent discussion of the "hypogeum palace" tomb construction and materials see Niroumand, H., Hosseini, S., Gültekin, A. B., Barceló, J. A., Osmadi, A., and Mahdavi, F. 2020. Structural analysis of earth construction’s vaults: Case of underground tombs of Chogha Zanbil. Revista De La Construcción. Journal of Construction, 19/3, 366–80.

properties.trench_location: under rooms 10 and 11, "hypogeum palace" in the "royal quarter"
properties.Disposal area: 70 x 56 m unbaked brick tomb building with 5 subfloor tomb chambers
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: 2 perpendicularly set vaulted chambers, both with cremated remains, l. 6.15/6.60 m, baked bricks of normal 35 x 35 x 10 cm format used throughout (for all 5 tombs in building), vault rests on long walls, from beginning of vault each brick overhangs previous by a few cm, and the bricks gradually tilt following curve of vault until 7 vertically placed bricks form the key (irregular radius of 1.72 m at start and 1.65 m at key certainly intended, as the large diameter and lack of specially moulded bricks necessitated a larger key); staircase of 16 steps; staircase vault made of half-bricks and whole bricks gradually inclined to arrive at 1 vertically placed brick (the key) flanked on each side by 2 bricks wedged at upper ends by fragments of bricks cut into a point; joints of chamber and staircase vaults all 1.5 cm composed of 1 layer of bitumen between 2 layers of lime, vaults and walls covered with a 1.5 cm layer of lime coated with plaster; slab floors of both rooms covered with 1 bitumen layer (3 cm thick) between 2 layers of plaster mixed with fine earth; entrance door sealed with 8 unbaked and 9 baked brick layers, staircase filled entirely with unbaked bricks, and 2 beds of baked bricks set on top; a clandestine shaft dug down into staircase, through door, and into chamber
properties.Other excavator notes: 13th century date; both chambers contained charred bones and ashes of indistinguishable number of individuals disturbed and crushed by the robbers; Tomb III is offset in relation to the walls of room 11, and generally, the position of the tombs in relation to the building above suggests that the tombs were built first and after their completion the building was constructed above with errors in the planning
properties.Data source: Ghirshman 1968: 59, 62, 65, pl. XLI; plan XI; fig. 26
properties.Data collator notes: for recent discussion of the "hypogeum palace" tomb construction and materials see Niroumand, H., Hosseini, S., Gültekin, A. B., Barceló, J. A., Osmadi, A., and Mahdavi, F. 2020. Structural analysis of earth construction’s vaults: Case of underground tombs of Chogha Zanbil. Revista De La Construcción. Journal of Construction, 19/3, 366–80.

properties.trench_location: under room 22, "hypogeum palace" in the "royal quarter"
properties.Disposal area: 70 x 56 m unbaked brick tomb building with 5 subfloor tomb chambers
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted chamber with 1 primary inhumation and 2 cremations, l. 15 m, w. 4.10 m, h. 3.80 m, baked bricks of normal 35 x 35 x 10 cm format used throughout (for all 5 tombs in building), vault rests on long walls, from beginning of vault each brick overhangs previous by a few cm, and the bricks gradually tilt following curve of vault until 7 vertically placed bricks form the key (irregular radius of 1.72 m at start and 1.65 m at key certainly intended, as the large diameter and lack of specially moulded bricks necessitated a larger key); left of chamber door (h. 1.85 m), a baked brick white-plastered platform (l. 2.25 m, w. 2 m, h. 0.80 m) raised on the side of the wall, from which it was slightly separated; floor composed of 2 layers of baked bricks coated with a 4-5 cm thick layer of plaster, and a 2cm thick layer of bitumen; chamber door sealed with 12 layers of baked bricks covered with 6 layers of unbaked bricks; staircase of 17 steps with vault made of half-bricks and whole bricks gradually inclined to arrive at 1 vertically placed brick (the key) flanked on each side by 2 bricks wedged at upper ends by fragments of bricks cut into a point; joints of chamber and staircase vaults all 1.5 cm composed of 1 layer of bitumen between 2 layers of lime, vaults and walls covered with a 1.5 cm layer of lime coated with plaster; entire stairwell opening covered by 3 x 7 rows of unbaked bricks closed at top by 2 baked bricks slabs separated by plaster mixed with fine earth.
properties.Body position: primary inhumation: on left side, hips flexed 110°, knees flexed 60°, arms flexed, left hand under cheek
properties.Vessels (pottery): on floor at east corner of platform, near head of primary inhumation: 2 unbaked clay vessels with tall foot topped by a bowl with pierced walls [or small fire stands] containing ashes of charcoal or incense; on floor at west corner of platform: 1 vessel same as previous (all 3 in pls. XLIII,1-2, XLIV,5, XCI, G.T.Z. 982, 983, 984), 1 clay bowl (pl. XLIV, 4; pl. XCI, G.T.Z. 987); at feet (on platform): 1 goblet; at feet (beside platform): 1 goblet (pls. XLIV,6, XLIII,2, XCI, G.T.Z. 985, 986)
properties.Vessels (metal): next to 3rd deceased [ashes on west side?]: handle of 1 gold vase (pls. XLIV,3, XCI, G.T.Z. 977), silver vase fragments (pls. XLIV,2, XCI, G.T.Z. 978)
properties.Jewellery: amongst ashes of 2nd deceased [in centre of platform?]: 2 copper/bronze bracelets (pls. XLIV, 1, XCI, G.T.Z. 972, 978), 1 hollow copper/bronze torque (?) (pls. XLIV,1, XCI, G.T.Z. 971); fragments of copper/bronze headband, 1 thin gold leaf (pl. XLIV,3)
properties.Weapons: next to 3rd deceased [ashes on west side?]: lapis lazuli dagger handle inlay fragment (pls. XLIV, 3, XCI, G.T.Z. 979)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: amongst ashes of 2nd deceased [in centre of platform?]: pieces of a glass paste and bitumen object (pl. XCI, G.T.Z. 975); 1 copper/bronze buckle (pls. XLIV,1, XCI, G.T.Z. 974); next to 3rd deceased [ashes on west side?]: 1 copper/bronze buckle (pls. XLIV,1, XCI, G.T.Z. 980)
properties.Other excavator notes: 13th century date; only tomb in the complex with a funerary platform, on which lay the intact skeleton, possibly female, and 2 piles of ashes and charred bones of 2 cremated individuals that had been wrapped in red-painted woollen cloth, of which only the border was still visible; a wall of room 11 encroaches on part of the entrance to Tomb IV, and generally, the position of the tombs in relation to the building above suggests that the tombs were built first and after their completion the building was constructed above with errors in the planning
properties.Data source: Ghirshman 1968: 59, 62, 67-71, 127-144; pl. XLII, XLIII, XLIV; pl. XCI; plan XI; fig. 27, 28, 29
properties.Data collator notes: for recent discussion of the "hypogeum palace" tomb construction and materials see Niroumand, H., Hosseini, S., Gültekin, A. B., Barceló, J. A., Osmadi, A., and Mahdavi, F. 2020. Structural analysis of earth construction’s vaults: Case of underground tombs of Chogha Zanbil. Revista De La Construcción. Journal of Construction, 19/3, 366–80.

properties.trench_location: under rooms 9 and 20, "hypogeum palace" in the "royal quarter"
properties.Disposal area: 70 x 56 m unbaked brick tomb building with 5 subfloor tomb chambers
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: 2 perpendicularly set vaulted chambers; 1st chamber damaged, only back wall still standing, 2nd chamber, l. 9 m, vault intact; baked bricks of normal 35 x 35 x 10 cm format used throughout (for all 5 tombs in building), vault rests on long walls, from beginning of vault each brick overhangs previous by a few cm, and the bricks gradually tilt following curve of vault until 7 vertically placed bricks form the key (irregular radius of 1.72 m at start and 1.65 m at key certainly intended, as the large diameter and lack of specially moulded bricks necessitated a larger key); entrance staircase preserved only a few steps (their baked bricks removed), and the walls that supported the vault; as in the other tombs, the bricks were joined with 1 layer of bitumen between 2 layers of lime, vaults and walls covered with a 1.5 cm layer of lime coated with plaster; 2 shafts made by robbers in tomb;
properties.Possible additional grave goods: chambers empty, but room 19 above contained bone and ash remains and the following items probably probably brought up from the tomb by robbers: 1 lugged jar (pls. XXXVII,4, LXXXVIII, G.T.Z. 900), ivory fragments, 2 frit spoons (pls. XXXVI,5, LXXXIV, G.T.Z. 784, 795) 4 frit pyxis lids (pls. XXXVI,9, LXXXIV, G.T.Z. 785, 786, 821, 822), 1 frit cup (pl. LXXXIV, G.T.Z. 790), frit knife handle (pls. XXXVI,7, LXXXIV, G.T.Z. 782), frit whetstone (imitation) (pl. XXXV,5; pl. LXXXII, G.T.Z. 781), fragment of copper/bronze relief plaque (pl. LXXXV, G.T.Z. 792); 1 copper/bronze monkey pin head (pl. LXXXV, G.T.Z. 917), 1 copper/bronze tweezer (pl. LXXXV, G.T.Z. 816), 1 copper/bronze dagger (pls. XXXVI,11, LXXXV, G.T.Z. 788); 1 copper/bronze button (pl. LXXXV, G.T.Z. 789), 1 alabaster mace (pls. XXXVII,7, LXXXV, G.T.Z. 787), frit beads (pl. LXXXV, G.T.Z. 783), 4 cylinder seals
properties.Other excavator notes: 13th century date; generally, the position of the tombs in relation to the building above suggests that the tombs were built first and after their completion the building was constructed above with errors in the planning
properties.Data source: Ghirshman 1968: 54-55, 59, 62, 71-74, pl. XLV; plan XI; fig. 30
properties.Data collator notes: for recent discussion of the "hypogeum palace" tomb construction and materials see Niroumand, H., Hosseini, S., Gültekin, A. B., Barceló, J. A., Osmadi, A., and Mahdavi, F. 2020. Structural analysis of earth construction’s vaults: Case of underground tombs of Chogha Zanbil. Revista De La Construcción. Journal of Construction, 19/3, 366–80.

properties.Vessels (pottery): at left shoulder: 1 jar (h. 10 cm) [cf. stump-base jars with moulded necks in Ville Royale II, early Neo-Elamite levels 8-9, Miroschedji 1981, fig. 22]
properties.Other excavator notes: pit burials 1-4 (ids ChZ12-15) dug very close to the royal palace
properties.Data collator notes: pit burial ids ChZ12-15 visible in pl. LXIII.1 at the same level, probably all fairly contemporary at the Middle Elamite to Neo-Elamite transition

properties.trench_location: 100 m from "tombe construite" 2 (id ChZ17), near the sanctuary of Nusku
properties.Disposal area: not located under a building
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: chamber (vault lost), unbaked brick, l. 3 m, w. 1.4 m, benches on both long sides (1 skeleton on each), plastered walls, entance to chamber closed by a stone slab; access well, approximate l. 1.5 m, w. 1 m, still 1 m deep, also closed by a stone slab
properties.Alignment (orientation): both individuals: NE-SW (head NE), face directed to NW
properties.Body position: both individuals: on right side, legs flexed 110° at hips, 45° at knees, arms flexed, hands at face
properties.Vessels (pottery): on floor near benches: 1 copper/bronze lamp; 3 terracotta goblets (pl. XCVIII, G.T.Z. 1121,a-b)
properties.Vessels (metal): on floor near benches: 1 copper/bronze lamp
properties.Jewellery: on left bench: necklace of beads in carnelian, agate, lapis, chalcedony, and rock crystal (pls. LXIV,4, XCVIII, G.T.Z. 1119); on right bench: 4 copper/bronze bracelets with open ends
properties.Glyptic: on left bench: 1 stone stamp seal; on right bench: lapis cylinder seal
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: on right bench: 1 sheet of worked copper/bronze (pl. XCVIII, G.T.Z. 1118)

properties.trench_location: 100 m from "tombe construite" 1 (id ChZ16), near the reservoir
properties.Disposal area: not located under a building
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted chamber, l. 3 m, w. 1.5 m, unbaked brick walls and vault, 3 benches along walls (2 sides and back), interior coated with lime; access shaft, l. 1.5 m, w. 1 m, reinforced with broken baked bricks; stone slabs closed the access well and entrance to the chamber; near east corner, a rectangular cavity with a skull and some bones (probably intended for the bones of earlier occupants, which were pushed back to make room for subsequent ones)
properties.Vessels (pottery): 3 locations in the tomb, in groups of 4: 14 goblets (pl. XCVIII, G.T.Z. 1124 and fig. 44) [leaves 2 goblets unaccounted for]
properties.Jewellery: on left bench: necklace of carnelian, lapis, and agate beads (pls. LXV,3; XCVIII, G.T.Z. 1123), 2 copper/bronze rings, 2 silver hair coils; on right bench: 2 hollow copper/bronze anklets, 1 copper/bronze bracelet covered with a thin sheet worked in copper/bronze (pls. LXV,4, XCVIII, G.T.Z. 1125, 1126); on back bench: fragments of copper/bronze rings, piece of 1 copper/bronze ring, 1 copper/bronze bead, 1 copper/bronze hair coil (pl. XCVIII, G.T.Z. 1127)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: on left bench: 1 small grey flint (pl. XCVII I, G.T.Z. 1122)
properties.Other excavator notes: minimum of 3 skulls, bones scattered on the 3 benches; tomb appears to have been disturbed

properties.Disposal area: not located under a building
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted unbaked brick chamber, l. 3.2, w. 1.5, lime-coated walls, vault collapsed, 2 steps lead from door down to bottom of chamber, 1 bench along left wall, 1 bench along back wall; unbaked brick access well, l. 1.2 m, w. 0.80 m, plastered walls, 5 steps lead to chamber door
properties.Vessels (pottery): distributed through tomb: 25 grey terracotta goblets in 3 varieties (pl. XCIX, G.T.Z. 1134-1136), 3 small bowls (pl. LXVI,4; pl. XCIX, G.T.Z. 1133), 4 lamps (pls. LXV 1.3, XCIX, G.T.Z. 1130-1131-1132)
properties.Jewellery: 1 lapis bead, 1 agate bead, 1 carnelian bead (pl. XCIX, G.T.Z. 1129), 2 copper/bronze rings (pl. XCIX, G.T.Z. 1128)
properties.Other excavator notes: 9 successive inhumations, the last one on the back bench, bones on left bench quite disturbed

properties.Disposal area: in a structure [abandoned?]; two brick walls run along the NE and SE sides of the burial with very little gap between; these walls underlie Igihalki walls
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: baked brick vaulted tomb, average dimensions: external l. 2.25 m, w. 1.10 m; internal l. 1.85 m, w. 0.80 m, 30 cm high brick walls supporting a tilted row vault, rear wall of vertically set bricks, front wall of horizontally set bricks, floor formed from 6 rows of 3 of neatly laid baked bricks; bricks are of 3 sizes: 26 x 26 x 9 cm; 30 x 30 x 9 cm; 30 x 19 x 9 cm; in situ photograph appears to show horizontal bricks at the bottom of a partly excavated access well
properties.Alignment (orientation): SSW-NNE, one skull was SSW-NNE (head SSW), face directed to approximately E
properties.Vessels (pottery): outside northwest long wall of tomb: large ceramic storage vessel crushed by the pressure of the earth (Taf. 10, DN.12-1227-51); inside tomb: in front of the face and behind the head, respectively of the best-preserved interment: minimum 1 goblet, 1 fragmentary narrow-necked jar (?); at foot end of interments: 1 small jar [possibly Taf. 10, D.N.12.1227-57]; along the northwest wall: at least 5 goblets [amongst which may be Taf 10 D.N.12.1227-59, D.N.12.1227-60, D.N.12.1227-61, D.N.12.1227-65]
properties.Jewellery: on finger of one skeleton: 1 copper/bronze finger ring
properties.Animal remains: outside northwest long wall of tomb next to storage vessel: animal bones (sheep?)
properties.Other excavator notes: remains of 3 skeletons in the tomb; relationship with the walls running next to walls of the burial is unclear; the tomb may be later than these walls, but still earlier than the Igihalki walls that overlie these walls; vessels (all depicted in Taf 10) are comparable with 17th century Ville Royale A vessels from Susa

properties.Vessels (pottery): 3 small painted Susa I-style vessels still intact (fig. 14 1, 2 and 3): a small jar with short, tubular spout, a small "marmite" with lugs, and a tiny "marmite" without lugs
properties.Data collator notes: perhaps the same burials with painted vessels mentioned in Mecquenem 1928b: 115

properties.Body position: on back, legs extended, arms brought to head level
properties.Weapons: next to skull: a small polished stone axe (which "could have accompanied the dead") (pl. XIX.7)
properties.Other excavator notes: skeleton appeared to be coated in red vermillion ochre from thorax to knees, and traces of ochre also on the forehead; the pigment that had impregnated the bones must have originally dyed a textile that had disappeared, leaving only the mineral component of the dye
properties.Data source: Dollfus 1975: 23, figs. 5, 6, pl. X.c, possibly pl. XIX.7; 1978, fig. 4

properties.trench_location: NW-SE cut just behind 1934 trench [which unearthed id Jaf1]
properties.Body position: on back, legs extended, arms brought to head level

properties.trench_location: NW-SE cut just behind 1934 trench [which unearthed id Jaf1]
properties.Disposal area: near pavement
properties.Other excavator notes: skull and ribs preserved; found near a pavement near a kiln, close to 2 hoes, 1 mace, large number of sherds and milling utensils

properties.trench_location: NW-SE cut just behind 1934 trench [which unearthed id Jaf1]
properties.Disposal area: abandoned area (?)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: pit, l. 2.2 m, w. 0.85 m, d. 0.90 m, filled with loose soil and covered at one end with a bed of gravel; at bottom of pit where the skeleton lay, the long walls were bordered by two small walls, the southern one (806) made of half bricks (26 x 18 x 20 cm), the northern one made of bricks placed vertically
properties.Body position: on back, legs extended, one arm brought to the skull level, the other stretched along the body
properties.Vessels (pottery): beside skull: 1 conical goblet with rounded base (34), 1 small jar

properties.Disposal area: periphery or outside of the residential area; dug into natural earth with no immediately surrounding structures noted
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, l. 2.76 m, w. 1.56 m [interior dimensions judging by photograph]; main chamber composed of a tilted row vault that appears to be set directly on the paving [i.e., not elevated on horizontal courses of bricks], back wall composed of horizontally set bricks; floor on natural soil, not paved
properties.Alignment (orientation): documented only as being on a different orientation to tomb 2
properties.Other excavator notes: tomb looted
properties.Data source: Zalaghi, A. and Rafiei-Alavi 2018; Zalaghi, A. 2018
properties.Data collator notes: contemporary with tomb 2 (id TaJ2), which contained vessels that appear to be coeval with Ville Royale A XII

properties.Disposal area: periphery or outside of the residential area; dug into natural earth with no immediately surrounding structures noted
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, l. 1.71 m, w. 1.15 m [interior dimensions judging by photograph]; access shaft of l. 1.01 m, w. 0.88 m [interior (?)] constructed of horizontally laid bricks, main chamber composed of a tilted row vault that appears to be set directly on the paving [i.e., not elevated on horizontal courses of bricks], back wall appears to be composed of vertically set bricks; floor paved with bricks
properties.Alignment (orientation): documented only as being on a different orientation to tomb 1
properties.Vessels (pottery): on floor of antechamber: 6 intact vessels [fig. 5 shows 2 of them, both jars, cf. Gasche 1973, group 21b, especially pl. 22.10, Ville Royale A XII]; 1 bowl-shaped lamp with a half-cover and traces of burning (fig. 5)
properties.Other excavator notes: tomb looted
properties.Data source: Zalaghi, A. and Rafiei-Alavi 2018; Zalaghi, A. 2018
properties.Data collator notes: tomb dimensions don’t appear to be correct based on photographs; vessels appear to be coeval with Ville Royale A XII

properties.Disposal area: within a partly excavated mudbrick building (residential, or in abandoned residence); between tomb 1 (id Tap5) and north wall
properties.Alignment (orientation): W-E (same as tomb next to it), face directed to S
properties.Body position: on back, left forearm resting on stomach
properties.Other excavator notes: skeleton measured 160 cm in length and unpublished photographs by Ganjavi suggest it was a young woman; not clear if burial was earlier or later than the tomb

properties.Disposal area: within a partly excavated mudbrick building (residential, or in abandoned residence), southern side of tomb 1 (id Tap5), outside tomb entrance
properties.Other excavator notes: vessel contained a "child" skeleton

properties.Disposal area: within a partly excavated mudbrick building (residential, or in abandoned residence); 2 m south of tomb 1 (id Tap5) (same room)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: found with burial 3 (id Tap4) inside another large pot with at least 3 horizontal mouldings, and thick rim
properties.Other excavator notes: remains of a "child" skeleton in vessel; one of two vessel burials found together in another larger pot which had no bones (vessel 4; cf. Haft Tappeh large vessels in building level II/Middle Elamite I)

properties.Disposal area: within a partly excavated mudbrick building (residential, or in abandoned residence); 2 m south of tomb 1 (id Tap5) (same room)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: pot "size" 49 cm; found with burial 2 (id Tap3) inside another large pot with at least 3 horizontal mouldings, and thick rim
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: nearby: "a copper/bronze artefact" [a thin copper-base object, perhaps a tool?] (fig. 11, 6)
properties.Other excavator notes: remains of two "child" skeletons in vessel; one of two vessel burials found together in another larger pot which had no bones (vessel 4; cf. Haft Tappeh large vessels in building level II/Middle Elamite I); bricks of tomb do not match that of walls, and therefore the tomb and other burials are taken as being later than the structure

properties.Disposal area: within a partly excavated mudbrick building (residential, or in abandoned residence); in room with 3 vessel burials and a pit burial (ids Tap1-4)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, rectangular, exterior 2.35 x 1.30 m, with tilted row vault which appears to be set directly on the pavement/ground, access well on the east side composed of horizontally laid bricks; brick sizes 28/27 x 25 x 7, 28 x 24/23 x 7, 25/23 x 26 x 25 x 6
properties.Other excavator notes: excavated by Saied Ganjavi (Ganjavi 1976); not excavated thoroughly and not well documented; lies 3.5 m northeast of tomb 2 (id Tap6); it seems that the tombs were on the same level, yet the connection between them is unknown because the area between trenches 1 and 2 was not excavated so it is not clear it they were built within the same building/complex

properties.Disposal area: a few meters west of ids Tap1-5, possibly within the same partly excavated mudbrick building (residential, or in abandoned residence)?
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, exterior 3.40 x 2.10 m, vault [in situ photograph appears to show a tilted row type] set on 10 horizontal courses of bricks, rectangular main chamber with access well on southern side; brick size 35 x 36 x 8; 32 x 32/31 x 6.5 cm; preserved height of west wall 0.90 m, east wall 1.20 m; only eastern part of vault preserved
properties.Alignment (orientation): described in text as E-W, but shown in sketch as S-N and in photograph at 90° to the W-E tomb 1
properties.Other excavator notes: excavated by Saied Ganjavi (Ganjavi 1976); not excavated thoroughly and not well documented; lies 3.5 m southwest of tomb 1 (id Tap5); it seems that the tombs were on the same level, yet the connection between them is unknown because the area between trenches 1 and 2 was not excavated so it is not clear it they were built within the same building/complex

properties.level_stratigraphy: upper part of level 2, which ranges in date from ca. 2500 to 1800 BCE
properties.Disposal area: under a "late Elamite pavement"
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: large oval vessel made of coarse yellow baked clay, numerous rope-like horizontal bands [cf. vessel dated to the late Akkadian era by Steve and Gasche 1971, pl. 5:42]
properties.Other excavator notes: amongst a dozen vessel burials of three types found within 1-3 m under a "late Elamite pavement"; bones fragmentary; directly after the reference to these burials, the possibility that small clusters of 20 or so bricks arranged in 2-3 layers here and there in the excavations could be covers for burials

properties.level_stratigraphy: upper part of level 2, which ranges in date from ca. 2500 to 1800 BCE
properties.Disposal area: under a "late Elamite pavement"
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: deep bowl-shaped vessel [described as a cover of known Akkad/Larsa date by Dyson 1966:7] joined to a series of baked clay rings/cuffs of the same diameter placed vertically, one atop the other and the assemblage often pierced with holes [as in the example in fig. 322]
properties.Other excavator notes: amongst a dozen vessel burials of three types found within 1-3 m under a "late Elamite pavement"; bones fragmentary; directly after the reference to these burials, the possibility that small clusters of 20 or so bricks arranged in 2-3 layers here and there in the excavations could be covers for burials

properties.level_stratigraphy: upper part of level 2, which ranges in date from ca. 2500 to 1800 BCE
properties.Disposal area: under a "late Elamite pavement"
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: baked coarse yellow clay vessel, h. 60 cm, hemispherical form open at both top and bottom, 3 horizontal mouldings on lower part of wall
properties.Other excavator notes: amongst a dozen vessel burials of three types found within 1-3 m under a "late Elamite pavement"; bones fragmentary; directly after the reference to these burials, the possibility that small clusters of 20 or so bricks arranged in 2-3 layers here and there in the excavations could be covers for burials

properties.Disposal area: below level of Middle Elamite (?) temples, towards the border of the tell
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: a large, well-built massif of bricks, bitumen and plaster containing a trio of tombs; the tombs were small corbelled vaults ("the length of a man") narrowing towards the summit, the last row of bricks leaving a small opening that was closed by a row of bricks placed vertically on the point, and supported by the masonry of the massif; the body was laid on a bed of bitumen
properties.Other excavator notes: tomb was filled with earth, fragments of bricks and pottery, and animal bones; in one tomb two faience knobs with inscriptions of Shilhak-Inshushinak were found; the only remains of bones were tiny fragments
properties.Data collator notes: presumably the knob ended up in the tomb via the fill (?)

properties.Disposal area: "under pavements ruined by Assyrians"; sacred area (?)
properties.Other excavator notes: "Elamite", "last epoch of the Susian kingdom"; date based on position "under pavements ruined by Assyrians"

properties.Disposal area: cemetery outside city wall; southwest edge of the Acropole (in the "grande tranchée")
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: "burials", superimposed over each other, sometimes entangled
properties.Vessels (pottery): near head: vessels, usually 3-4 but up to 5; 6 main forms: 1. truncated cylinder in very fine yellow or greenish paste, painted exterior (most burials had only one) (figs. 5-7); 2. cup with a more or less developed base, same paste as 1, decorated internally with paintings (1-2 per burial) (figs. 8-9); 3. spherical cup, usually less fine paste than 1 and 2, exterior painted with circles or simple motifs (1-2 per burial) (fig. 10); 4, same as 3, with a spout, often ornamented exterior (fig. 11); 5. Same as 4 but with 4 lugs, usually pierced, and no spout, generally ornate exterior (figs. 12, 14); 6. plain grey stone or coarse clay horn-shape vessel with bulbed base (l. 6.3-12.2 cm; mouth dm. 3.7-4.5 cm), few in number and only found in female burials, where it is frequently accompanied by a metal mirror, some still contain gray mineral matter, remains of decomposed make-up (figs. 15, 18); "small cylindrical vessels" listed as rarer finds
properties.Vessels (stone): burials of women frequently contained small conical makeup vessels (preserving decomposed makeup); in female burials a small horn-shaped vessel in clay or grey stone terminating in a ball; 2 small alabaster rectangular containers, one 37 mm at the base, h. 43 mm (fig. 26), the other smaller; 2 cylindrical bituminous stone vessels
properties.Jewellery: near head: jewellery; both men and women had necklaces of small white, grey and black beads ("almost all" had them on p. 7; "rarely" on p. 9); "amulets" (some made from pierced painted pottery sherds); long beads all made from the same paste and with similar paintings to those of vessels; amulet in form of a white-veined gray limestone "nail" (fig. 21), 2 beads (fig. 22), a shell fragment cut on a tooth-shape (fig. 24), half a flat white limestone bead with crossing lines [a seal?]
properties.Weapons: near head: weapons; burials of men often contained an axe or tool in copper; copper celts, primitive axes inspired by similar tools in polished stone, but thinner, all are the same shape (elongated, slightly swollen middle, square on the lateral edges, slightly flared at the cutting edge (figs. 27, 28), variable sized but similar in proportions (largest is l. 220 mm), on some fragments of cloth were preserved by the oxide (regular, well-woven fabrics, with either warp thread stronger than the weft, in others warp and weft equal strength); total of 5 maces (stone maces are more abundant – 5 fragments in the necropolis 1. black limestone, h. 80 mm (can still see in the interior the trace of the instrument with which it was pierced by rotation (fig. 36), 2. white limestone h. 42 mm (fig. 37), 3 white limestone h. 40 mm, fragmentary, pierced with a small hole crossing it along the height (fig. 38), 4. red limestone, ¾ complete, h. 35 mm, pierced with 3 holes (fig. 39), 5. white limestone, pierced with two opposite holes [3 of the 5 deposited in a broken state])
properties.Tools: near head: "instruments"; burials of men often contained an axe or tool in copper; a broad instrument with a cutting edge (spatula?) (fig. 29); rare copper scissors (fig. 30), a punch (fig. 31), a needle (fig. 32) l. 180 mm, dm. 2 mm; rare spindle whorls
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: burials of women frequently contained a metal mirror (figs. 33, 34), plain copper discs polished on one or both sides (dm. 92-172 mm, thickness 1.5-2.5 mm); sometimes small terracotta cylinders (l. 46-59 mm, dm. 15-19 mm), often simply broken vessel spouts, decorated with painted circles (fig. 19), only one occurred in each tomb when encountered, probably served as amulets, as did sherds cut into discs and pierced in the middle (fig. 20); (fig. 25); occasional (found more in the layers) tiny triangular polished black stone hatchet (amulet?) (l. 41 mm, cutting edge w. 38 mm, fig. 35); near the head of a man, a spatula-shaped natural polished pebble (fig. 40)
properties.Other excavator notes: the furnishings were almost always the same, varying only in no. of painted or unpainted vessels; skeletons crushed and often reduced to powder; burials very close to each other; in 1943, Mecquenem claims that there were only adult burials [i.e., the child burials were in sondage 2 within the settlement area] and they had been exposed, since their completely emaciated remains were buried in a necropolis mound; in the 1936-1937 season he says that he worked around the necropolis that had been excavated from 1907 to 1909, and finished what remained of it; we recall that it was a mound in the shape of a truncated cone of about 3 m. high and a dozen meters in diameter at the base; the burials were crowded together; bundles of bones, often a skull in a cup, long bones in goblets; it is therefore certain that these were second-degree burials and it is incorrect, as Morgan (1912: 7) wrote, that the bodies were most often placed elongated, it is still not correct that the necropolis had an area of 750 m* (1912: 2); it was about 120 m2; the author counted without (p. 6) doubt the space cleared around the mound, before his arrival, to facilitate the work and enlarge the circle of searches
properties.Data collator notes: Mecquenem 1928b: 100 wrote: "we recall without insisting […] that these inhumations were in the second degree, meaning that the body had been interred or exposed previous to their deposition in the cemetery; the skull was often in a cup; the leg bones assembled in a goblet"; however, the description of Morgan implies that often they were complete skeletons; not secondary burials (an important recent comparison for late fifth millennium BCE primary burial is the cemetery at Tole-e Chega Sofla recently excavated by Abbas Moghaddam, e.g., Moghaddam, A. (2018) Six Thousand Years Old Cemetery at Tole-e Chega Sofla (published by RICHT); note that in the years Mecquenem claims to have worked in the necropolis again (1936-37) no records of it appear in the annual reports

properties.trench_location: Apadana, western part under remains of a third court and brick-paved vestibules
properties.level_stratigraphy: from around 60 cm down to around 3 m below the palace pavement
properties.Data collator notes: the large cylindrical vessels for burials sound like late Sukkalmah/early Middle Elamite

properties.level_stratigraphy: 20 m x 3 m trench below the tiled floor
properties.Other excavator notes: trench details: a backfill of gravel, mixed with glazed bricks fragments continued to a depth of 2.50 m below the pavement, the excavation was reduced to 6 m in length in the middle part and the depth pushed to 4 m (below pavement), we then reached the clay of the earthwork core where there were funerary vessels similar to those obtained 3 m lower in the necropolis to the east of the palace (i.e., 7 m)
properties.Data collator notes: dating: cf. vessel burials at -7 m in the trench to the east of the palace, i.e., ca. mid/late Sukkalmah

properties.Other excavator notes: "Neo-Babylonian" date; an earlier excavation (from 1913) resumed in 1935, descended to 6 m deep. In the centre of the court, the tiling had sunk into a depression more than 1 m deep due to the large Elamite vaulted tombs completely collapsed underneath; the paving had to be frequently removed and the voids filled with gravel, glazed brick fragments and earth. Below the rubble, we recognized carbon layers, evidence of presence of plants; in these layers we found bones of domestic animals in abundance; below was the ancient Elamite cemetery; we collected pottery and many fragments of glazed frit vessels (e.g., square pyxis).
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1935: 4, pl. 31 (square pyxis, photograph after excavation); 1943: 35, fig. 28 (square pyxis); Wicks 2019, SuU-G12

properties.Other excavator notes: "Elamite" date; an earlier excavation (from 1913) resumed in 1935, descended to 6 m deep. In the centre of the court, the tiling had sunk into a depression more than 1 m deep due to the large Elamite vaulted tombs completely collapsed underneath; the paving had to be frequently removed and the voids filled with gravel, glazed brick fragments and earth. Below the rubble, we recognized carbon layers, evidence of presence of plants; in these layers we found bones of domestic animals in abundance; below was the ancient Elamite cemetery; we collected pottery and many fragments of glazed frit vessels.
properties.Data collator notes: date suggested based on the tendency of Mecquenem to apply an "Elamite" date to Sukkalmah and Middle Elamite-dated material

properties.trench_location: Apadana palace, west court, south chantier
properties.Vessels (silicious): fragments of several bottles and containers with a square base in glazed frit
properties.Other excavator notes: many burials in poor condition with almost all the vessels broken; they were found below a thin carbony layer representing the decomposition of grasses with numerous remains of animals, horses, donkeys, sheep and cattle, this thin layer was under approximately 4 m of sterile earth embankment
properties.Data collator notes: omitted from Wicks 2019

properties.Vessels (pottery): vessels, sometimes in glazed baked clay and amphorae
properties.Data collator notes: Mecquenem (1922: 5) makes a reference to pl. XI, which is incorrect

properties.level_stratigraphy: top of vault ca. 0.30 m below paving [base perhaps slightly over 2 m depth]
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, l. 5 m, w. 3 m, h.3 m, collapsed, carefully constructed; in situ photograph suggests a height closer to 2 m with a radial type vault with a "massif" casing of horizontally placed bricks; the front entryway is formed by wedge-shaped "voussoirs", but the interior construction is not visible; door on the east side preceded by a small case (antechamber) of 0.87 m interior surrounded by a wall
properties.Vessels (pottery): in main chamber: ceramic vessels that had suffered with the vault's collapse
properties.Vessels (silicious): in main chamber: 1 glazed frit vessel
properties.Tools: in main chamber: 1 small copper/bronze tool, 1 polished hard stone axe
properties.Glyptic: in main chamber: 1 carnelian cylinder seal
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1922: 5, plan II, fig. 12 (in situ photograph); 1922c: 132-3; Amiet 1972: pl. 187, no. 2169; Miroschedji 1981a: 34; Wicks 2019, SuC4, pl. 8

properties.level_stratigraphy: up to 2 m below paving; at about base level of "tomb A" (id Sus13)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: in situ photograph shows an upright-set (?) vessel, at least 1 horizontal moulding [form not clear enough to determine comparanda]
properties.Other excavator notes: lay about 3-4 m south of "tomb A" (id Sus13)
properties.Data collator notes: one of 4 vessels huddled together (ids Sus14-17); their position in relation to tomb A in the situ photograph suggests that they were in or slightly above the level of a large room described as follows in Mecquenem 1922: 5 and 1922c: 133: "at 2 m deep [below the pavement], appeared on the cleared surface traces of mud walls surrounding a square room; the walls were isolated, and the chamber carefully explored without result [in 1922 with the additional comment that "there was perhaps a funerary chapel there"]" (these walls are depicted in 1922, plan II)

properties.level_stratigraphy: up to 2 m below paving; at about base level of "tomb A" (id Sus13)

properties.Other excavator notes: lay about 3-4 m south of "tomb A" (id Sus13)

properties.Other excavator notes: lay about 3-4 m south of "tomb A" (id Sus13)
properties.Data collator notes: one of 4 vessels huddled together (ids Sus14-17); their position in relation to tomb A in the situ photograph suggests that they were in or slightly above the level of a large room described as follows in Mecquenem 1922: 5 and 1922c: 133: "at 2 m deep [below the pavement], appeared on the cleared surface traces of mud walls surrounding a square room; the walls were isolated, and the chamber carefully explored without result [in 1922 with the additional comment that "there was perhaps a funerary chapel there"]" (these walls are depicted in 1922, plan II)

properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, l. 3, w. 2 m [interior/exterior not stated], baked bricks, in situ photograph shows a tilted row vault set on side walls composed of 7 courses of horizontally laid bricks, solid front and rear walls composed of horizontally laid bricks, a small room in front of the entrance door on the west side, entry to vault seems to be closed by bricks placed vertically
properties.Vessels (pottery): in room in front of door: 3 small terracotta vessels; in vault: 4 small ovoid vessels in blackish terracotta
properties.Other excavator notes: 4 skulls recognized inside the vault
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1922: 5, figs. 13-14 (in situ photographs), plan II; 1922c: 133
properties.Data collator notes: in situ photograph Mecquenem 1922, fig. 18 shows a tomb captioned as tomb B, but the tomb shown is clearly tomb D (id Sus20)

properties.level_stratigraphy: about 2 m below paving, around the same level as tomb B (id Sus19)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vaulted tomb, in situ photograph shows a tilted row vault with rear wall of vertically set bricks, "steps" at the front topped by two bricks set vertically to close the tomb
properties.Other excavator notes: 2 bodies inside the chamber
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1922: 5, figs. 17-18 (in situ photographs), plan II; 1922c: 133
properties.Data collator notes: in situ photograph shows this tomb close to a group of 5 burials in vessels with covers pierced by a hole (ids Sus23-27): hole-ring pots first appear around the 16th century BCE (Gasche 1973, group 35a, pl. 44.3-6, Ville Royale A XII, group 35b, pl. 44.2, Ville Royale A XI); comparable double-vessel burials with hole-ring vessel covers were noted at Haft Tappeh in building level II (Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2010, Taf. 68-69), which yielded radiocarbon dates of 1525-1435 BCE (Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2016: 98)

properties.level_stratigraphy: about 2 m below paving, same level as tomb D (id Sus20)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: one frequently finds inside or at the foot of these vessel burials rounded pebbles, which appear to have been fossil sea urchins [cf. "river pebbles" in Gasche 2000, pit burial S.189/Ghirshman: A XIII, T.P.T. 8 and overturned coffin S.177B/Ghirshman: B VII, TJ. 4]

properties.level_stratigraphy: about 2 m below paving, similar level to tomb B (id Sus19)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: vessel of yellow pottery, coated internally with bitumen (h. 39 cm, dm. 38 cm), closed with an inverted red pot
properties.Tools: at foot of burial vessel: 1 flint blade, 1 nucleus
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: inside burial vessel: clay figurines of 3 naked females holding their breasts, 1 naked, bearded musician playing a viol, and 1 bed model (fig. 16)
properties.Other excavator notes: remains of two "children" in vessel
properties.Data collator notes: date based on figurines

properties.level_stratigraphy: about 2 m below paving, same level as tomb D (id Sus20)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: overturned vessel pierced by a hole used as a cover [possible second upright-set vessel underneath, i.e., double vessel burial)]
properties.Vessels (pottery): resting on hole of burial vessel: 1 small round bottle [pottery?]
properties.Other excavator notes: one of a group of 5 vessel burials (ids Sus23-27) close to tomb D (id Sus20)
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1922: 6, fig. 18 (in situ photograph with caption incorrectly stating tomb B, which must be corrected to D); 1922c: 133
properties.Data collator notes: in situ photograph fig. 18 shows all 5 vessels, at least 4 overturned, and 3 of them clearly with holes in the bases; hole-ring pots first appear around the 16th century BCE (Gasche 1973, group 35a, pl. 44.3-6, Ville Royale A XII, group 35b, pl. 44.2, Ville Royale A XI); comparable double-vessel burials with hole-ring vessel covers were noted at Haft Tappeh in building level II (Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2010, Taf. 68-69), which yielded radiocarbon dates of 1525-1435 BCE (Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2016: 98)

properties.level_stratigraphy: about 2 m below paving, same level as tomb D (id Sus20)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: overturned vessel pierced by a hole used as a cover [possible second upright-set vessel underneath, i.e., double vessel burial]
properties.Tools: inside burial vessel: 1 grain grinder separating remains of the two "children"
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: inside burial vessel: 1 terracotta figurine
properties.Other excavator notes: vessel contained two "children" separated by a grain grinder; one of a group of 5 vessel burials (ids Sus23-27) close to tomb D (id Sus20)
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1922: 6, fig. 18 (in situ photograph with caption incorrectly stating tomb B, which must be corrected to D); 1922c: 133

properties.level_stratigraphy: about 2 m below paving, same level as tomb D (id Sus20)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: overturned vessel pierced by a hole used as a cover [possible second upright-set vessel underneath, i.e., double vessel burial]
properties.Other excavator notes: vessel contained a skeleton of a "child"; one of a group of 5 vessel burials (ids Sus23-27) close to tomb D (id Sus20)
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1922: 6, fig. 18 (in situ photograph with caption incorrectly stating tomb B, which must be corrected to D); 1922c: 133
properties.Data collator notes: in situ photograph fig. 18 shows all 5 vessels, at least 4 overturned, and 3 of them clearly with holes in the bases; hole-ring pots first appear around the 16th century BCE (Gasche 1973, group 35a, pl. 44.3-6, Ville Royale A XII, group 35b, pl. 44.2, Ville Royale A XI); comparable double-vessel burials with hole-ring vessel covers were noted at Haft Tappeh in building level II (Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2010, Taf. 68-69), which yielded radiocarbon dates of 1525-1435 BCE (Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2016: 98)

properties.Other excavator notes: close to coffin H (id Sus33)
properties.Data collator notes: link of the wheel to this burial is unclear; described as one of 5 inverted terracotta coffins (ids Sus34-38) separated by walls, but location marked on plan away from this group and instead close to coffin H (id Sus33)

properties.Data collator notes: "richest" coffin of id Sus80-G; recorded in Mecquenem 1943-44 in "funerary mound B", in this case certainly the east court; all 4 accounts of the assemblage differ, see table 3 in text; In Mecquenem 1929–30 arrowheads listed but no dagger; in Mecquenem 1943–44 copper/bronze vessels totaled 3 and lay between elbows/knees, axe and dagger at feet under coffin rim, bracelet not decorated, earrings absent, and a pierced ivory rod on top of burial

properties.date: possibly very late Susa III or early-mid Susa IVA
properties.level_stratigraphy: 3.5-4 m below palace pavement, directly below the overturned coffins level (coffin ids Sus80-G, Sus81-87)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: burials "on the ground", very entangled, the earth of the burials had been pounded (packed in/compounded)
properties.Vessels (pottery): terracotta vessels, often large several are painted (e.g., pl. 8 bottom [small vessels with hatched triangles on shoulder dated Susa C by Le Breton 1957, pl. XXVI.7, one occurs in Susa III/level 18 in Carter 1980, fig. 13.2, but the painted versions should be late, postdating the incised ones; one of the spouted knobby vessels is Louvre Museum Sb 376], and pl. 9 top), generally geometric decorations, but some depict birds and wild goats; vessels usually empty but several topped by an inverted bowl
properties.Vessels (metal): bronze vessels, 1 with incised decoration (pl. 7 bottom [=Mecquenem 1924b: 114, fig. 8/Amiet 1966: 208, pl. 154, which Muller-Karpe 1993: 28 places in variant 3 II b with an Early Dynastic IIIa vessel from Tello, Tell K])
properties.Weapons: copper/bronze weapons (weapons specified as arrowheads in Mecquenem 1924b: 114)
properties.Other excavator notes: clearing the vessels was very difficult because they were so tightly packed into the earth; in Mecquenem 1924b p. 113, this level with burials "completely different" to the coffin burials is placed at 3.5 m; in Mecquenem 1924b: 114 the vessel decoration is generally "geometric, more rarely, to the triangles, to the parallel lines, are added representations of animals, plants; the paints are black, red, white, and not very solid."
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1924: 2-3, pls. 8 bottom and 9 top (vessels after excavation, only some relevant); 1924b: 113-114, figs. 7-8
properties.Data collator notes: ids Sus89-91 belong to this group; position directly below the overturned coffins level seems to suggest a hiatus (or a clearing of the intervening level/s for construction)

properties.trench_location: Apadana, trench to the northeast of the palace
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: at foot of burial vessels: some more or less coarse representations of human heads, sometimes simply in coarsely colored clay (alternatively, rough representations of human heads, sometimes in coarsely colored clay observed near the burials in Mecquenem 1922c: 118 [a comment that also seems to pertain to the sherd burials found nearby])
properties.Other excavator notes: burial vessel contained bones
properties.Data collator notes: found around the overturned coffin burials ids Sus120-124; note that Mecquenem says in 1926 (1926b: 2-3) in relation to the find of a head in a ca. Ville Royale A XII-dated tomb in Ville Royale sondage 1, that "the presence of a model in a tomb is not an isolated fact in Susa; in a tomb from the beginning of the Elamite kingdom, we found a bread of unbaked earth, whitewashed with lime, roughly marked on the thumb: two eyes, one line for the base of the nose, another for the mouth" – this reference in Mecquenem 1922 is the only prior mention of heads, so these may be what he is referring back to in 1926.

properties.level_stratigraphy: 5 m deep (or 5 m below level of palace)
properties.Vessels (pottery): terracotta vessels (glazed terracotta vessels in Mecquenem 1922c)
properties.Jewellery: carnelian beads; around forearm bones: copper/bronze bracelets
properties.Other excavator notes: northwest of the Ville Royale, about 5 m deep, the "Elamite" level, indicated first by fragments of inscribed bricks, a few tablets of unbaked earth, of Anzanite writing; then burials (i.e., this id). Below were glazed frit vessels decorated with torsades or a network in relief, ivory buttons, small copper/bronze vessels, inscribed Elamite bricks, an inscribed fragment of a cone; in Mecquenem 1922c: 117-118 the find is reported as 1912 excavations to the east of the palace of Darius yielding burials (i.e., this id) 5 m below the level of the palace. In 1913, enlarging this excavation, we found an Elamite level with bricks, inscribed tablets, and a multiplicity of burials [probably Middle Elamite/Neo-Elamite I, id Sus148-G] suggesting a necropolis: at 8 m. deep, we found an Elamite wall including bricks inscribed with the name of Temti Halki, Kutir Nahhunte. Shilhak Inshusinak, relief bricks, fragments of Elamite decorative panels
properties.Data collator notes: appears to be a trench further east of the trench to the east of the palace, at the northwest edge of the Ville Royale (marked in plan 1)

properties.level_stratigraphy: below 5 m deep (or below 5 m below level of palace) "Elamite level"
properties.Other excavator notes: northwest of the Ville Royale, about 5 m deep, was the Elamite level, indicated first by fragments of inscribed bricks, a few tablets of unbaked earth, of Anzanite writing; then burials [probably NE II, id Sus147-G]. Below were glazed frit vessels decorated with torsades or a network in relief, ivory buttons, small copper/bronze vessels, inscribed Elamite bricks, an inscribed fragment of a cone; in Mecquenem 1922c p. 117-118 the find is reported as 1912 excavations to the east of the palace of Darius yielding burials (id Sus147-G) with furniture of glazed terracotta vessels 5 m below the level of the palace. In 1913, enlarging this excavation, we found an Elamite level with bricks, inscribed tablets, and a multiplicity of burials suggesting a necropolis: at 8 m. deep, we found an Elamite wall including bricks inscribed with the name of Temti Halki, Kutir Nahhunte, Shilhak Inshusinak, relief bricks, fragments of Elamite decorative panels
properties.Data collator notes: appears to be a trench further east of the trench to the east of the palace, at the northwest edge of the Ville Royale (marked in plan 1)

properties.Vessels (silicious): frit vessels
properties.Other excavator notes: "Elamite" date; trench one of a series of cuts around the Ville Royale excavated in 1914: a trench in the north, proceeding "bit by bit into the heart of the tell"
properties.Data collator notes: probably the same trench as ids Sus147-G and 148-G from AR 1913 in a trench further east of the trench to the east of the palace, at the northwest edge of the Ville Royale (marked in plan 1)

properties.trench_location: Apadana, trench to the east of the palace, northern part
properties.Vessels (pottery): generally pottery of quite coarse baked clay

properties.Other excavator notes: to the west of the Ville Royale northern cut of 1914, an artificial mound constituted of a heap of burials (4.5 m deep, 70 x 30 m in plan), whose summit reached almost the level of the palace; a pile of mostly pit burials comprising an "artificial mound"; sometimes only a skull found in the bottom of a vessel, always too damaged for conservation; bones crushed and incomplete

properties.trench_location: Apadana, trench to the east of the palace northern part
