properties.Construction, container, wrapping: collapsed vault, interior l. 5 x w. 2 m, constructed from large tiles of red baked clay sealed in bitumen, preceded by an access well with a very small entrance door, walls and vault covered with lime plaster; construction made at the bottom of an open pit; once the masonry was finished, the vault was covered up to the level chosen for the orifice of the well
properties.Jewellery: a few beads, copper/bronze belt buckles
properties.Other excavator notes: bones and rubble formed a 10 cm thick layer; "Neo-Babylonian"/"end of Elam" date
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1943: 48, fig. 41, Tombeau A; Wicks 2019, SuC19, pl. 16
properties.Data collator notes: excavation year unknown - not identifiable in annual reports; since trench is not known, the geographic co-ordinates are given for Ville Royale sondage 1, which is the most central trench availabile

properties.Construction, container, wrapping: corbel vaulted tomb, interior l. 2.9 x w. 1.5 m; walls of both baked and unbaked bricks; lime-plastered interior; no recognisable access well, but a small covered landing 0.75 m long, the wall pierced by small entry window; a pavement of baked bricks covered the vault; construction made at the bottom of an open pit; once the masonry was finished, the vault was covered up to the level chosen for the orifice of the well
properties.Other excavator notes: layer of bones and plaster, no grave goods found; "Neo-Babylonian/"end of Elam" date
properties.Data source: Mecquenem 1943: 48, fig. 41, Tombeau B; Wicks 2019, SuC20, pl. 16

properties.Data collator notes: burial probably dates ca. 13-11th century based on a similar amulet with same combination of snake and dagger symbols held by the Lamashtu (unique to Susiana) in a "child" burial at Chogha Zanbil (see id ChZ1; Mecquenem and Michalon 1953: 51-52); since trench is not known, the geographic co-ordinates are given for Ville Royale sondage 1, which is the most central trench availabile

properties.Alignment (orientation): on plan 2 pit appears approximately E-W
properties.Vessels (pottery): pottery [cf. Gasche 1973, group. 16, pl. 17.2 and 4, Ville Royale B VI]
properties.Jewellery: bronze bracelets and spiral rings of types found in Ville Royale I grave 507 (Shimashki/early Sukkalmah, level 3, Carter 1980, fig. 47.7 [actually fig. 48])
properties.Other excavator notes: oldest burial of the "troisième état" level (generally equating to Ville Royale B VI-V/Ville Royale A XV), and the material collected could date this burial to earlier than material from the rest of "third state" (perhaps to the Shimashki period); in this extreme zone of the tell, this would be the first Elamite installation at the beginning of the 2nd millennium after a hiatus following the Susa II period

properties.Weapons: 1 dagger with partly preserved wooden handle, 1 axe, 1 votive lance-head decorated with animals
properties.Tools: 1 whetstone with copper/bronze ibex handle (resembling Luristan examples)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: an iron palette with copper/bronze handle
properties.Other excavator notes: 9th-7th centuries date
properties.Data collator notes: dated "Neo-Elamite" in Wicks 2019, but probably late Middle Elamite (see e.g., Miroschedji 1990: 184, and summary of recent dating attempts in Mofidi-Nasrabadi 2013, Tab 4)

properties.Vessels (silicious): a painted polychrome cubic pyxis
properties.Pins: 2 clothing pins placed in parallel, one at each shoulder, with tips pointing downwards, presumed to have fixed a female garment
properties.Data source: Miroschedji 1990: 183-84, fn. 7, 186; Heim 1992: 208, fig. 146; Wicks 2019, SuP7

properties.trench_location: Ville Royale I (expansion of base of R. de Mecquenem's sondage 1)
properties.level_stratigraphy: bottom of burial pit below bottom of level 18 walls; pit cut either from level 17 or 18
properties.Disposal area: dug in the soft trashy fill outside the two main structures of level 18
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: a bitumen-coated wooden coffin to hold the body with a second similar coffin placed over it as a lid, the side and ends of the coffin have lids (perhaps to hold the two containers together or for handles or supports)
properties.Alignment (orientation): NE-SW (head NE), face directed to SE
properties.Body position: on left side, arms flexed, hands at face, legs flexed at around 45° at the knee
properties.Vessels (pottery): outside coffin at head end: 5 small jars (fig. 7.1-5), 2 large jars (fig. 8.1-2), miscellaneous sherds; all the vessels carry faint traces of red wash and/or bands of white paint
properties.Vessels (metal): outside coffin at head end: 2 identical trough-spouted copper/bronze hemispherical bowls (fig. 6a-b)
properties.Jewellery: inside coffin in front of hip: 1 black stone bead (fig. 6c)
properties.Possible additional grave goods: outside coffin at head end: 10 rectangular baskets
properties.Other excavator notes: wooden coffin is the first one known from Susa although similar ones have been found al Ur (making reference to Woolley 1934: 137)

properties.trench_location: Ville Royale I (expansion of base of R. de Mecquenem's sondage 1)
properties.level_stratigraphy: appears to have been cut from level 12 or 13 into the fill in 14
properties.square_locus: heavily eroded section between squares C-14 and D-14
properties.Weapons: 1 copper/bronze mace head (socket preserved traces of wooden handle; fig. 22b), 1 copper/bronze axe (socket preserved traces of wooden handle; fig. 22c), 1 copper/bronze hook (fig. 22a)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: 1 copper/bronze 1 belt (fig. 22d), traces of a shield or chariot wheel once covered in bitumen (fig. 21)
properties.Other excavator notes: contained no skeleton but the objects and their mutual association suggest a burial similar to those found by Mecquenem; contemporary with Mesopotamian Early Dynastic IIIa

properties.trench_location: Ville Royale I (expansion of base of R. de Mecquenem's sondage 1)
properties.level_stratigraphy: pit cut from level 11 into the fill in level 13, cut through walls of levels 11 and 12; burial disturbed by Parthian well 508
properties.Disposal area: cut the western wall of room 560
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: pit, oval; body wrapped in a bitumen-coated reed mat.
properties.Alignment (orientation): approximately SSE-NNW (head SSE), face directed to W
properties.Body position: on left side (but torso seems to have fallen slightly on the back), arms flexed, hands at vessel in front of face, legs flexed perhaps around 45° at the knee
properties.Vessels (pottery): behind back: 1 large jar with finger-impressed bands (fig. 24.1); behind the hips: 1 small painted pot (fig. 24.3); in front of face: 1 pot with applied handles (fig. 24.2)
properties.Other excavator notes: likely contemporary with grave 555 (id Sus1165) (Mesopotamian Early Dynastic IIIa) or slightly later (Mesopotamian Early Dynastic IIIb)

properties.trench_location: Ville Royale I (expansion of base of R. de Mecquenem's sondage 1)
properties.level_stratigraphy: pit dug from level 8 into wall 533 of level 9B
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: pit, irregular oval; traces of reed matting beneath and on top of the skeletons
properties.Body position: individual 1 (underneath): on right side, hips flexed at 90°, knees at 10°, arms flexed, hands at face; individual 2 (op top): on left side hips flexed at 45°, knees flexed at 45°, arms flexed, hands at face
properties.Vessels (pottery): at head of individual 1: 1 jar, 1 conical bowl; at head of individual 2: 2 jars, 1 conical bowl used as a lid for one of the jars (fig. 33)
properties.Other excavator notes: 2 adults placed one on top of the other; southern part of burial pit cut by Mecquenem’s sondage 1 trench
properties.Data collator notes: the numbers assigned to the 5 vessels in the fig. 31 sketch of the burial do not match the numbers of the 4 vessels (1 carinated pot, 1 double-angle pot, 1 ridged-shouldered jar, and a conical bowl) depicted in fig. 33

properties.trench_location: Ville Royale I (expansion of base of R. de Mecquenem's sondage 1)
properties.level_stratigraphy: pit cut from level 7 surface and its bottom rests on 8 surface; burial subsequently disturbed
properties.Alignment (orientation): SSW-NNE (head SSW), face directed to NNW
properties.Body position: on left side, legs flexed, left hand placed on the hip, the right flexed with hand at shoulder (text), on left side, hips flexed 90°, knees at 10°, right hand at hip and left at shoulder (burial sketch)
properties.Vessels (pottery): in front of face: 1 ridged-shouldered jar (fig. 32.1); slightly higher in the pit but almost certainly belonged to burial: sherds of 1 semi-carinated pot (fig 32.2); 2 bowls (fig. 31.3,5) found in a disturbed context at a still higher level, but may belong to the burial since they were found in association with a large shoulder sherd if the ridged-shouldered jar (fig. 32.1)
properties.Other excavator notes: burial disturbed

properties.trench_location: Ville Royale I (expansion of base of R. de Mecquenem's sondage 1)
properties.level_stratigraphy: pit probably cut from level 4B or 5 (commenced below the tops of fallen-melted bricks that lay just below the 4B floor level), bottom of pit on the 6A surface
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: pit filled in with mudbricks, sherds and loose clay (the bricks possibly remains of a collapsed superstructure built over the grave); traces of reed matting below skeleton
properties.Alignment (orientation): NW-SE (head NW), face directed to SW
properties.Body position: on right side, right hip flexed 90°, knee at 45°, left hip flexed approximately 110°, knee at 45°, right arm flexed 90°, left arm flexed 45° with hand at mouth
properties.Vessels (pottery): beyond head: 2 double-angled jars (fig. 42.3-4), 4 indented band-rim bowls (fig. 41.1-4), 2 bowls (fig. 42. 1-2)
properties.Jewellery: worn on left hand: 2 copper/bronze finger rings (fig. 43a-b); worn on wrists: 2 copper/bronze bracelets [one on each wrist] (fig. 43c-d); on skull: 1 diadem of linked lead or tin rings (fig. 43e)
properties.Animal remains: disarticulated sheep-goat bones in the jars and bowls
properties.Data collator notes: the vessel forms are similar to those found in the Shimashki/early Sukkalmah grave 507, but the pots are squatter and less sharply angled (this same change is witnessed from the Ur III to the Shimashki period in the Ville Royale B trench levels VII (Ur III) and VI (Shimashki)

properties.trench_location: Ville Royale I (expansion of base of R. de Mecquenem's sondage 1)
properties.level_stratigraphy: level 3; the bottom of the grave pit was found below the level 3 foundation floor and appears to have been contemporary with the architecture of that level
properties.Disposal area: found below room 598 of the level 3 building [building function not specified, but could be a residential burial?]
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: pit, irregularly shaped oval; both individuals wrapped in reed mats coated with bitumen
properties.Body position: one individual appeared to have knees flexed at about 10°
properties.Vessels (pottery): 3 incurved rim bowls (fig. 45.1-3), 3 upright indented band-rim bowls (fig. 45.4-6), 18 double-angled jars (figs. 45.7-9, 46.1-12, 47.1-3; date pits inside 46.6); 1 round-based jar with red-washed neck containing animal teeth (fig. 47.7), 2 unbaked pottery bases (fig. 47.4-5), 1 unbaked pottery bowl (fig. 47.6), 1 handmade pot with handle (fig. 47.8)
properties.Vessels (metal): 2 shallow copper/bronze dishes inside one another (fig. 48a)
properties.Jewellery: 9 finger or ear rings (figs. 48f-n), 1 copper/bronze anklet (48e), 1 copper/bronze bracelet (fig. 48d) (all simple cast bands bent to fit)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: 1 disintegrated cloth bag containing a lump of yellow ochre
properties.Other excavator notes: the pottery vessels were placed in two groups: one consisted of 2 bowls and the larger of 4 bowls, 16 double-angled jars [but these vessels can't be equated with specific vessels in the figures]; the unbaked pottery, the lump of ochre and the exceptionally large number of pottery vessels may indicate the profession of at least one of the occupants during their life; the food remains and the size range of the pottery and metal saucers suggest that several sets of dishes and a meal were buried with the dead
properties.Data collator notes: jumbled adult skeletons indicating multiple consecutive inhumations (i.e., burial at separate times) with skull of the first skeleton perhaps displaced when the second individual was interred; alternatively, the loose skull next to pot 30 (in fig. 44) may be part of a secondary burial; grave goods not assignable to particular individuals

properties.Disposal area: under floor of level 15A habitation
properties.Alignment (orientation): E-W (head E), face directed to S
properties.Other excavator notes: skeleton preserved; plan drawing shows infant-sized child; no grave goods
properties.Data source: Le Brun 1971: 190, figs. 32, 34.1, pl. XX.1 (trench image)

properties.Disposal area: under floor of level 15A habitation
properties.Alignment (orientation): S-N (head S), face directed to W
properties.Jewellery: small beads of soft stone (probably a bracelet)
properties.Other excavator notes: partly destroyed by a ravine; plan drawing shows infant-sized child
properties.Data source: Le Brun 1971: 190, figs. 32, 34.1, 62.14, 68.11, pl. XX.1 (trench image)

properties.Construction, container, wrapping: secondary interment of a skull in a small pit
properties.Other excavator notes: according to Le Brun, indicates that secondary burials also took place outside of the funerary mound of the Acropole where they were found by Morgan (1912: 6-13) and Mecquenem (1928: 100; 1943: 5-6)
properties.Data source: Le Brun 1971: 170, 207, fig. 32; seal in fig. 35.7, pl. XXII.10

properties.trench_location: Acropole, west face of funerary massif
properties.level_stratigraphy: placed in the ashy layer covering level 11B
properties.Disposal area: in contact with the bricks of the funerary massif wall, and slightly set into the masonry
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: secondary interment, remains of the top of a skull and 2 fragments of long bones (femur and tibia) [but note the tomb appeared to have been disturbed and destroyed by earlier excavations by Mecquenem], placed in a sort of case constructed in unbaked bricks, one brick laid flat to form the base, and 4 bricks stood vertically to form the walls, 8 bricks placed vertically for the cover, bricks measure 40 x 30 x 11 cm

properties.trench_location: Acropole, northwest side of funerary massif
properties.Disposal area: in a recess in the masonry of the massif
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: case made of unbaked bricks; the niche of the massif formed the base; two bricks laid vertically formed the north and west walls [not clear if two per side]; cover made of two rectangular bricks measure 45 x 30 x 11 cm
properties.Other excavator notes: contained a skull enveloped in a fine mat; south part destroyed by work of Mecquenem

properties.age: 4 adults (2 x unknown age, 1 x 50 years [F]; 1 x 30-40 years [M]), 2 juveniles (1 x 6-7 years, 1 x 1-2 months)
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: collapsed unbaked brick vault (bricks 38-39 x 38-39 x 9 cm) with an entry shaft pit (691) preserved to 1.4 m length (one end destroyed by Mecquenem); vault deeply embedded, crossing from level 8 to level 11 fill and probably not visible from the surface; constructed in a pit l.2.8 x w.2.75-2.5 x d.2 m; main chamber h.1.3 m; accessed through door of h.70 x w.60 cm; a 1.8 x 0.35 m central pit (found filled with earth) cleared 25 cm below level of lateral benches; benches comprised of 7x3 rows of bricks, placed on edge in the west; courses of horizontally-laid bricks form the short walls and a small vault-shaped niche (35 x 25 cm) was cut into the 6th-9th courses of rear wall; walls rest on pavement and lean against the excavation surface; thin layer of white-ish matter on floor, perhaps from decomposed mats; the tomb was re-opened for the 4th burial and much material was pushed aside during the 5th and 6th inhumations; at the end of its life the tomb entrance was closed by a large globular pot and the access well filled with a homogenous fill (sherds mostly level 7 and some level 8 types); vault started to fall apart during its use and collapsed after 6th inhumation
properties.Vessels (pottery): at entrance: 1 large globular pot (fig. 38.9); 1 amphora (fig. 35.14); 2 jars (fig. 34.7, 9); inside tomb: thousands of sherds, but few vessels intact or reconstructible, no apparent patterns in spatial distribution, but more numerous amphorae fragments near periphery confirm they were stood up against walls; individual 1: 2 amphorae (fig. 35.13, 35.15) covered at mouth by small bowls (fig. 35.2-3); a third small bowl; individual 4: offerings of pottery containing particularly dates and animal remains
properties.Vessels (silicious): individual 1: 4 glazed clay bottles (fig. 39.30-33), 3 at presumed head location; individual 2: 1 glazed ceramic bottle (fig. 39.28) against wall near presumed skull location; individual 3: 3 glazed clay bottles (fig. 39.26, 27, 29) against west wall near feet
properties.Jewellery: individual 1: shell finger ring (fig. 40.2), 6 copper/bronze finger rings (fig. 40.6-11), 6 beads (fig. 39.1-2, 5, 7, 14-15)
properties.Pins: individual 2: iron pin with gold-covered head (fig. 40.5) at feet and another pin at an unspecified location
properties.Weapons: individual 2: long iron knife with recurved tip (fig. 46.15); individual 3: iron dagger (fig. 40.14)
properties.Glyptic: individual 4: faience cylinder seal (fig. 40.1) below skull (at chest level of female individual no.2)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: individual 2: iron sheet fragments at thorax level, perhaps a belt plaque
properties.Other excavator notes: bones jumbled from successive inhumations and crushed by vault; presumed burial sequence: [individual 1] adult (on a mat?) in central pit, only leg bones preserved; [individual 2] adult on north bench; [individual 3] female ca. 50 years on south bench; [individual 4] male 30-40 years, original location unknown, remains dispersed; long bones of one leg (?) in anatomical connection against east wall, skull in south end above female no. 2; [individual 5] child 6-7 years against north wall; [individual 6] infant 1-2 months against south wall; grave goods generally not in primary position, attributions to specific individuals are speculative
properties.Data source: Miroschedji 1981: 24-35, figs. 3-4, 30-40, pls. VIII-XIII; Wicks 2019, SuC22, pls. 28, 34-44

properties.Construction, container, wrapping: two low, baked brick walls delimiting a burial space of 2.05 x 0.35 m; covered with bricks set on edge transversely; brick size 0.36 x 0.36 x 0.10 (?) cm
properties.Alignment (orientation): almost E-W, face directed to south
properties.Body position: torso turned to left side, legs extended, arms tightly flexed, hands pulled into the chest
properties.Vessels (pottery): at feet: 1 cup (fig. 29:7) covering 1 small globular jar (fig. 29:8), 1 small bowl (fig. 29:2), 1 coarse goblet (fig. 29:11); behind head: 1 cup (fig. 29:9) covering 1 small globular jar (fig. 29:10), 2 small bowls (fig. 29:5-6); in a sort of niche beyond head: 2 bowls (fig. 29:3-4) separated by 1 coarse goblet (fig. 29: 12)
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: a small unbaked clay object (29:1)
properties.Other excavator notes: height of buried individual 1.70 m+; soil contents of vessels 29:3, 4, 6, 10 and 12 were analysed by N. Miller (1981: 137-8, 140; report indicates material from 6 vessels was analysed, but the sixth listed is 29:1 which is not a vessel), all samples contained a high proportion of burnt dung and poplar/willow charcoal, they are not considered to represent burnt offerings, but rather grave fill in which funerary activities involving fire may explain the carbonised material present
properties.Data source: Miroschedji 1981: 25, fig. 29; Miller 1981: 137-8, 140; Wicks 2019, SuB2, pls. 28, 30

properties.Construction, container, wrapping: partly excavated, shape of pit not clearly discerned; covered by a brick structure which seemed to be part of it; 7 bricks placed slanted vertically over a floor 2 bricks in length, brick size 0.38-39 x 0.38-39 x 0.09 cm

properties.trench_location: left bank of Ala River, near Jubaji village, 21m above river level, 9m below highest point of modern mound, buried under river sediment
properties.Disposal area: surrounding pavement just above level of tomb suggests it was associated with a structure
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: rectangular chamber, 4.5 x 2.2–2.3 m, constructed with flat stones of varying size (largest is 56 x 11cm), mortared with sand, gypsum and mud; 6 courses of vertically placed stones reaching up to h. 60cm then rows start to step inwards, probably to form a vaulted ceiling; on the west side of chamber the excavator reconstructed a staircase leading down into an antechamber; bodies interred in 2 bronze coffins ("east coffin" and "west coffin"), placed side-by-side on opposing orientations in mainside chamber
properties.Alignment (orientation): tomb E-W; coffin: west coffin: SE-NW (head SE in rounded end of coffin), face directed to SW; east coffin: NW-SE (head NW in rounded end of coffin), face directed to NE
properties.Body position: both individuals: on left side, legs tightly flexed, arms flexed, hands near chest
properties.Vessels (pottery): in antechamber: 12 amphorae (6–17); variously inside chamber and antechamer: 5 large open vessels (1–5), 1 large corrugated jug (18) and 4 jug(?) bases (19–22), 21 conical bowls, some of which were used to close the mouths of the amphorae (23–43), glazed terracotta vessels including 3 mid-sized open vessels (1–3), 5 mid-sized bottles (4, 8, 14–15, 22) and 24 small corrugated bottles (9–13, 16–21, 23–35), a large painted bottle (36), 10 small painted bottles (37–46), 8 rectangular pyxides (47–53), a round pyxis lid (54)
properties.Vessels (metal): inside chamber [many of them in a heap of metal vessels against the north wall between 2 coffins]: copper/bronze vessels including 1 long-handled pan with female-fish figurine attachment (1/1), 4 female-fish figurines (pans lost) (1/2–1/5); 12 “chalices”, small jar (5/1), 12 “inkwells” (6/1–11, 8/1), 7 “teapots” (7/1–7), 5 small bowls (8/2–6), 4 large bowls (10/1–12/1), 1 ladle (13/1), 2 strainers (14/1–2); silver vessels including 1 long-handled pan with female-fish figurine (1), 1 “teapot” (2), 1 “inkwell” (4), 1 “chalice”(?) (7), 1 drinking vessel (3), 3 bowls (5–6:2)
properties.Vessels (stone): inside chamber or antechamber: 35 small (generally lugged) alabaster (?) vessels (1–35), 1 bituminous stone cup (1)
properties.Jewellery: inside chamber on wrist of individual in east coffin: 1 gold bracelet with re-cut inscribed eyestone inlay (4/1); inside chamber [or reassinged to chamber after tomb looted]: 22 silver bracelets (8/1–21), 17 gold bracelets (3/1–5/12 [excluding 4/1], 3/2 is inscribed), 33 gold-capped stone beads (7/1–3), 2394 gold beads of 41 styles (8/1–9/31), 327 pendants (11/2–7) [the 281 examples of 11/2 are biconical, matching those depicted on female figurines in the tomb], 2 gold hair (?) spirals (10/1), a woven gold rope necklace (11/1), 8 gold finger rings (12/1–13/3), 9 large gold clothing ornaments (14/1–6.4, with inlays including 14/4 with an inscribed Kurigalzu eyestone inlay), 1259 smaller gold appliques of 15 types (15/1–14), hundreds of semi-precious stone beads (4/1–13/17)
properties.Pins: inside chamber [or reassinged to chamber after tomb looted]: 36 gold clothing pins (6/1–36); 5 gold clothing pins with semi-precious stone heads (1/1–5)
properties.Weapons: inside chamber [or reassinged to chamber after tomb looted]: 7 iron blades (1/2–1/8), at least 4 dagger handles (including gold-covered 1/1), 1 copper/bronze (17/1) dagger, 1 silver-handled (9) dagger, 1 sword (?) with animal head handle (1/1), 2 chert arrowheads
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: inside chamber [or reassinged to chamber after tomb looted]: 1 female copper/bronze figurine detached from a mirror (2), 5 copper/bronze candelabra (3/1–5), 4 copper/bronze lamps (9/1–4), remains of 10 copper/bronze mirrors (15/1–10), 1 copper/bronze comb (?) (16/1), various small pieces of unidentified copper/bronze objects (18/1–20/3); 3 ceremonial(?) gold “rings” (2/1–2/3) (2/1 inscribed Shutur-Nahhunte son of Indada); various stone small items (2/1–4), 2 stone combs (?) (2/1–2), 3 bitumen items (2–4), 15 decorated ivory pieces (1–15), cotton textiles
properties.Data source: Shishegar 2008, 2015; Ahmadinia and Shishegar 2019; Wicks 2019: 246-49, pls. 57-69
properties.Data collator notes: in Wicks 2019: 249, objects listed as having been found outside the tomb were instead outside tomb Arj1; grave good numbers are references to plates in Shishegar 2015; tomb was looted prior to arrrival of excavator, therefore findspots (and even provenience) for many of the objects are unknown

properties.trench_location: left bank of Marun river at northern boundary of ancient Arjan
properties.Disposal area: subterranean, no constructions noted in the area
properties.Construction, container, wrapping: rectangular tomb chamber, l. 2.5 x w.1.36 x h. 0.9m, 3 stone-lined, gypsum-plastered walls, plastered floor, ceiling of 5 stone slabs coated with bitumen, east wall too damaged to reconstruct; body interred in a bronze U-shaped coffin (l.132 x w.60 x h.60cm), fragments of a decorated bronze lid, probably once fixed on by a decayed rope still tied around the coffin handles
properties.Alignment (orientation): tomb E-W, coffin NE-SW (out of alignment with tomb, probably moved when tomb flooded, originally E-W?), (head NE in rounded end of coffin), face directed to NW
properties.Body position: on right side, legs tightly flexed, arms flexed and crossed over chest
properties.Vessels (metal): outside straight (foot) end of coffin: 1 long-necked copper/bronze jar, 10 (or 13) copper/bronze chalices, 1 copper/bronze lion-headed beaker, 1 small silver jar with name inscription, 1 large bronze bowl (dm. 43.5 cm) with engraved decoration and name inscription
properties.Weapons: inside coffin at left side of torso: 1 dagger with iron blade and inlay-decorated handle
properties.Miscellaneous grave goods: outside straight (foot) end of coffin: 1 bronze and iron candelabrum with name inscription; at rounded (head end) of coffin1 copper/bronze lamp; inside coffin in left hand (?): 1 gold "ring" with name inscription; inside coffin near feet and under head: 12 cotton textile fragments; inside coffin in front of chest area: 98 gold textile appliques (34 rosettes, 64 discs); removed before excavators arrived, but attributed to the coffin: 1 broken, hollow silver tube with a conical perforated tip
properties.Possible additional grave goods: above chamber: 2 large, shattered jars probably associated with the burial, “carbonised matter” on ground surface (from smashed jars?); near chamber: 1 large stone bowl near tomb (one of the 2 “jars” above?), 1 clay tablet , contemporary with burial and probably related to it
properties.Other excavator notes: skeleton badly damaged; tomb had been flooded up to around 50cm depth and both tomb and coffin were filled with a layer of sediment
properties.Data source: Towhidi and Khalilian 1982; Alizadeh 1985; Álvarez-Mon 2010; Wicks 2019: 248-251, pls.70-74
properties.Data collator notes: name inscriptions refer to “Kidin-Hutran, son of Kurlush"
